snippet.title: WATCH: Full 2024 State of the Union address | MSNBC
snippet.description:
Watch President Joe Biden address both houses of Congress in his final State of the Union address of his term. 

» Subscribe to MSNBC: http://on.msnbc.com/SubscribeTomsnbc

About: MSNBC is the premier destination for in-depth analysis of daily headlines, insightful political commentary and informed perspectives. Reaching more than 95 million households worldwide, MSNBC offers a full schedule of live news coverage, political opinions and award-winning documentary programming -- 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

At 46:40 Joe says "Wall Street didn't build America – they're not bad guys, they didn't build it though – the middle class built the country, and unions built the middle class." Sounds like Joe is attempting to avoid animosity and bring people together here – rather than tear people apart like Donald does – however the fact is that the middle class contributed only only partly to building the US. Seems to me that the working class and, the slave class did most of the work, with help from the middle class – and also help from rich investors. "Venture capitalists" including Wall Street people, all contributed to building the US. But at least Joe made some attempt to bring us together, rather than attempted to make us fear and hate each other. By the way I'm saying this as someone who has been a member of most, if not all, of these "classes" of people – a factory worker, an artisan (proprietor of piano service business, tuning, adjusting, and repairing pianos), and who, having retired, has even made a living by as a capitalist, investing successfully in corporations. I've known and been friends with many people from all these "classes" of people. The United States, unlike some other countries,  is a place where one can move from one "class" to another, or become part of more than one class at a time, and where we people *can work together* with one another rather than fear one another – the thing that Donald encourages us to do.

Read it if y’all know how. 

What's in the immigration and foreign aid bill
The vast majority of the $118.2 billion bill would be spent on overseas aid rather than immigration.

That would include $60.6 billion to assist Ukraine in its ongoing war against Russia's invasion; $14.1 billion in funds for Israel in its war against Hamas' after Hamas' terror attack; $10 billion in humanitarian assistance to civilians both in Ukraine and in the Palestinian territories of Gaza and the West Bank; as well as $4.83 billion for some countries in the Indo-Pacific.

The Senate proposal also includes $20.23 billion for the southern border, to increase immigration restrictions and enforcement and implement new migrant policies.

The legislation crucially links the foreign money to immigration policy in a bid to ensure enough Republican support for it to pass through the divided Congress.

PHOTO: Migrants wait in line adjacent to the border fence under the watch of the Texas National Guard to enter into El Paso, Texas, May 10, 2023. 
Migrants wait in line adjacent to the b...Show more
Andres Leighton/AP, FILE
The funds to assist Ukraine include $19.85 billion to replenish military weapons, $13.8 billion for Ukraine to purchase weapons and munitions from the U.S. and $14.8 billion to support Ukrainian military training.

The bill also includes $8 million for the Department of Defense's watchdog to continue to exercise oversight over U.S. assistance to Ukraine.

Funding for Israel includes $4 billion for Israeli missile defense capabilities and $1.2 billion for the procurement of the Iron Beam missile defense system. The package also provides $2.44 billion to support U.S. operations and to replace combat expenditures for weapons in the Red Sea.

In the Indo-Pacific, the deal includes a $1.9 billion investment in the U.S. industrial base to replenish weapons provided to Taiwan, the self-governing island that China regards as a breakaway province. The Senate bill further includes $542.2 million for U.S. forces and $133 million to enhance the U.S. industrial base capacity for cruise missile components.

@@benfaunce7496 Are you just copying and pasting stupid responses? I didn't speak of any guns, gramps. Take your meds and go to bed already.

As a bonus can of worms.... this is from a website called practicalmachinist a question and snippets.
Why doesn't the cylinder length count in barrel length in a revolver? For that matter, why isn't chamber length deducted from a rifle's measurement? The bullet doesn't start from the breech face.
There are two parties interested in barrel length.
The manufacturers and consumers in one camp and the regulators in another.
I was considering the BATFE method of measuring barrels. Their concern isn't ballistics, but conceal-ability.
One can simply drop a dowel down the barrel of an unloaded firearm, from the muzzle end until it contacts the closed bolt/slide. Measure that length of the dowel and you will have the barrel length.
This usually includes the chamber.
The revolver is measured the same way if it has revolving barrels like a pepperbox.
I assumed the BATFE would be consistant and rational in including the chamber as a part of barrel length as the cylinder length affects conceal-ability. Silly me. That's too rational.
If the revolver has a cylinder separate from the barrel, the cylinder is not included in the measurement.

@@seanmadson8524 exactly.
​@@seanmadson8524they truly support everything he's trying to do for the American people!

@@icnohelp I don't deny that they support him. I'm just explaining why they employ this specific behavior of repetitive standing ovations, when it would be more natural to spread them farther apart and save them for particularly poignant moments

They did it to take up time. His speech had no substance, just sound bites of more “promises”. He doesn’t have time for these bills to even go through before November, so this is really just a campaign speech with free mass coverage.
@@seanmadson8524 because every statement has extraordinary meaning for the American people. I've heard people tell who were at home clapping and standing eventide he shared his plan for our future.

@@icnohelp Believe me, I loved this speech as an American thirsty for some reasonable action from our leaders. I was actually surprisingly moved by more than a few parts.

That being said, it still isn't natural for any human to give that many standing ovations that repetitively, especially when at least half of the audience is elderly. I've been to many concerts in my life, and they have shown me the average level of human endurance in conjunction with how that affects excitement, and I'm just saying that being at an event like that would be draining on its own without the celebration. This level of cheering requires more than appreciation, it serves a specific (and useful) purpose as I stated before.

It's fine that this was partly performative, it always is in the way I described in my first comment. That doesn't diminish this speech, it still hit hard in all the right places and was a pleasure to watch. My wife and I will be watching it again once she gets home from work, and I rarely watch speeches twice.

The Dems, being "progressives", and left of center, believe that the people of the country matter, and that they are due fundamental and unassailable rights to be able to vote, to have decent well-paying jobs, to have affordable healthcare, and decent federally-funded education, and a whole lot more, with at the core the idea of personal freedom subject of course to the law.

The GOP, on the other hand, reject this idea of freedom, since they see those existing on federal and state benefits - including those benefitting from education and affordable healthcare - as "freeloaders" who benefit from the money garnered by taxes "ripped" from the pockets of the "true" makers and shakers - i.e. those who have been financially successful and who have, for the most part, founded businesses supplying the jobs - and that these "freeloaders" do not deserve those benefits since they've done little or nothing to fund them. The GOP is all for total "freedom" for businesses and business-people and corporations to do completely as they see fit even if it means polluting the rivers and the skies, the freedom to drill and mine wherever they wish, even in national parks. The GOP believe that government should be ONLY about national security and maybe policing, and that's it - no need for "intrusive" Federal agencies. The GOP believe that putting the vote in the hands of the people is a grave mistake, and tantamount to arming a horde of unproductive bums with the right to tell corporations and the "Good Ol' People" what they should do. The GOP believe that democracy itself is a bad idea, and should be scrapped ... and there are deep, well-funded, decades-old plans, being brought to fruition as I write - to implement just that. The fact is, President Joe Biden and his predecessor, Donald Trump, were both eager to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan and end what Biden referred to in his Aug. 16 speech as “America’s longest war.”

The Trump administration in February 2020 negotiated a withdrawal agreement with the Taliban that excluded the Afghan government, freed 5,000 imprisoned Taliban soldiers and set a date certain of May 1, 2021, for the final withdrawal.

And the Trump administration kept to the pact, reducing U.S. troop levels from about 13,000 to 2,500, even though the Taliban continued to attack Afghan government forces and welcomed al-Qaeda terrorists into the Taliban leadership.
Biden delayed the May 1 withdrawal date that he inherited. But ultimately his administration pushed ahead with a plan to withdraw by Aug. 31, despite obvious signs that the Taliban wasn’t complying with the agreement and had a stated goal to create an “Islamic government” in Afghanistan after the U.S. left, even if it meant it had to “continue our war to achieve our goal.”

That may be particularly true of "swing voters", as those represent a population of people who aren't as politically committed. @@user-bk4xi9hh3v that doesn’t change the definition of a republic. Keep in mind that elections are performed in the United States through a democratic process known as voting. Maybe you’ve done it before. A republic and a democracy are not mutually exclusive; the United States has implementations of both systems. We are a “Federal Constitutional Republic” that democratically elects our representative officials. It wasn’t too long ago that we didn’t directly vote for senators. That actually used to be up to the State legislatures (respective to the senate seat at hand, for example Delaware state legislature would vote on the election of Delaware senators but had no authority to elect a Massachusetts senator). This was how our system worked until the passing of the 17th Amendment. The framers had in mind a wide system of hugely indirect democracy, and as our country evolved, more direct democratic reforms have since taken place.

Here’s the definition for republic:

Republic (noun): “A state in which supreme power is held by the people and their elected representatives, and which has an elected or nominated president rather than a monarch.”

Here's a bit of history which even though I was just a kid at the time, I still remember it; On August 15, 1971, in a nationally televised address, President Richard Nixon announced a significant economic measure known as the Nixon shock. This series of actions was taken in response to increasing inflation. The most notable components of the Nixon shock were:

Wage and Price Freezes: Nixon issued Executive Order 11615, imposing a 90-day freeze on wages and prices. This was the first time the U.S. government had enacted wage and price controls since World War II. The wage and price controls were intended to curb inflation, but their impact and effectiveness remain subjects of historical analysis. After the 90-day freeze, increases in wages and prices required approval by a “Pay Board” and a “Price Commission,” with an eye toward eventually lifting controls—conveniently, after the 1972 election.
